RuneScape uses Frame because JFrame wasn’t around till java 1.4.2 (I’m pretty sure), and RuneScape uses methods from like, Java 1.0 :P[/quote]Afaik rs2 was written after 5 came out. Its pointless to use swing for a game like rs, especially when it takes up more resources that aren’t needed.

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

AWT delegates all the drawing/component/w/e stuff to the host platforms GUI system. Each call to show() or hide() is just a wrapper for ShowWindow or what have you. Swing puts more of the processing into Java code so that you can set the flags, L & F, and other things at runtime. In this case, some graphics program that will probably be rendered by Protostribes own code, there is really no need to involve swing when all you need is a graphics surface to draw on.

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

Frame = AWT
JFrame = Swing

AWT is Swing’s predecessor and Swing is based of off it.

RuneScape uses Frame because JFrame wasn’t around till java 1.4.2 (I’m pretty sure), and RuneScape uses methods from like, Java 1.0

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @RLN RLN
item.description:
@RLN wrote:

[quote=“1337h4x, post:4, topic:61997”]I don’t know why youre pissed at me, but awt does really suck compared to swing.

Swing looks better.
Swing is faster.
Swing is easier to program.
AWT look stale.
AWT is slow.
AWT acts gay when with other swing components.
Swing is easier to program with.[/quote]
Awt is faster, they’re not supposed to be used together.
I agree swing looks “better” but personally I would prefer speed over aesthetics, although if it were a big/commercial program I would choose swing. A problem is also that awt is partially platform dependent, because its mostly native.
Also, swing is harder to use as it has panes and some extra knowledge is required

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

EDIT2: We should notice that you can only FAKE opacity of an GUI with the user's screen. There is no way to to make Frame's etc "clear" or "50%" visible. To fake opacity, take a screenshot of the application's location, width and height, using javax.robot or whatever you want such as using graphics-config to get the screen and use that as the background of said application. Make sense?
That was really random o.O

If it was pointed at me, I don’t know a better way to do it in AWT.

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

I was under the impression the “swing” package was just AWT implemented “correctly” and somewhat “basically”. 1337hax… you’re dumb as a fish…

I could be wrong, but AWT is far less demanding than swing…

But yes, they all have their uses; of course. And AWT doesn’t ever act gay, it is NOT slow, and it’s not all that hard to code with. Just learn what you’re doing before you open your face.

EDIT: Hah, even I don’t use it correctly all the time… I used the insets at the wrong time on my loader; proof. It should have been later when I called and set the sizes.

EDIT2: We should notice that you can only FAKE opacity of an GUI with the user’s screen. There is no way to to make Frame’s etc “clear” or “50%” visible. To fake opacity, take a screenshot of the application’s location, width and height, using javax.robot or whatever you want such as using graphics-config to get the screen and use that as the background of said application. Make sense?

Read full topic

Basically they both have their uses, which seems to be what semaphore was saying. You can tell how similar they are by just looking at the javax.swing.JFrame class, what does it extend? That’s right, java.awt.Frame

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

As a general rule of thumb, if you are using swing components, JFrame is the way to go. If you plan on creating your own custom components (paint method and all) the best approach would be to use awt. In reality there’s little difference in the grand scheme of things between awt objects and swing objects. (This is not to say there are NO differences… just not a bunch). The propaganda machine worked well in convincing a bunch of people that they were worlds apart.

1337h4x. The next time you feel like mocking one of your own kind, kindly take a look at your name and think long and hard about calling someone a ‘noob’. I have yet to read a single post you have ever made that has brought me more than a little bit of vomit in the back of my throat. If you are the genius none of us take you for please elaborate on your puerile comment about ‘awt’ sucking.

I anxiously await more gems of knowledge from your endless wellspring of thought.

Read full topic
